The Metropolitan Museum of Art (the museum) in New York announced today that it is planning to shutter its Guggenheim Museum, which has been open since 1985, and refocus on revitalizing the institution’s collection through the auction of works and open up online viewing rooms for the collection.The announcement follows the announcement last year that the museum was preparing to transition from a permanent collection to an online-only version. The museum has also invested more than $100 million in its archive since it moved online in 2008, and recently opened an artist’s studio in a former Douglas Fir Building in its underground parking lot. The center’s online exhibition program, which was being led by curator and artist Paul Efstathiou, has helped the museum achieve a nearly 90 percent drop in ticket sales this season

The next Biennial should be held in 2020, and the first in 2021.


The University of Haifa in Israel and the Israel Museum in Jerusalem have struck a deal to begin the construction of a new museum for the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) in the city of Nablus. The project, which involves the demolition of an older building and rebuilding a new one in the city, will be funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Arts (NEA).The two institutions first announced the project in July of 2017, and completed their expansions in October of 2017. The Israeli government contributed $2.3 million to the project, which will be located in the city of Nablus and will be inaugurated by a performance by the contemporary artist Basma al-Qasimi.The new museum will be designed by architect Nael Harel, and will be inaugurated by a series of galleries.
